meanings.sent1: She decided to externalise her thoughts by writing them in a journal.
meanings.sent2: The company chose to externalise their customer service to a third-party provider.
meanings.sent3: He tried to externalise his happiness by dancing around the room.
meanings.sent4: The artist externalised her emotions onto the canvas with bold strokes of color.
meanings.sent5: The magician's trick was to externalise a bouquet of flowers from an empty hat.

meanings.definition: To attribute to an external source.
meanings.sent1: The superstitious belief was to externalise bad luck to a black cat crossing your path.
meanings.sent2: The team tried to externalise the blame for the project's failure onto the weather conditions.
meanings.sent3: She would often externalise her forgetfulness to her busy schedule.
meanings.sent4: The politician tried to externalise the corruption scandal onto his opponents.
meanings.sent5: The ancient civilization used to externalise natural disasters to the anger of the gods.

meanings.definition: To express or make visible externally.
meanings.sent1: The artist externalised her creativity through her vibrant paintings.
meanings.sent2: The architect wanted to externalise the concept of sustainability in the design of the building.
meanings.sent3: The comedian externalised his humor through witty jokes and funny gestures.
meanings.sent4: The singer externalised her emotions through the powerful lyrics of the song.
meanings.sent5: The chef externalised his passion for cooking in the exquisite presentation of the dish.
